title: Ticket #4314: Shared port blocking
description:
Since shared port no longer forks, any blocking behavior is very painful.

I think I found a case where things currently block. It goes like this:

  • Client requests daemon X from shared port.
  • Shared port does socket passing to daemon X
  • Shared port returns to DC and registers the socket for callback, setting a deadline.
  • Daemon X does not respond. Deadline for client socket passes.
  • Shared port fires command handler, which calls get() on the socket. This may block completely or for some amount of time set by the socket's timeout.

We should call get() non-blocking regardless (in case if the daemon has a partial response, then goes to sleep) and we should make sure that if get() times out we fail the request if the socket's deadline has passed.
remarks:
2014-Apr-15 20:57:48 by bbockelm:
Pushed a fix. To test:

  1. Setup a personal condor instance with shared port enabled and D_FULLDEBUG for shared port.
  2. Submit a handful of fake jobs.
  3. SIGSTOP the startd.
  4. Observe the shared port logs. The schedd should start shadows that try to talk to the startd. These will have a deadline of 20s.
  5. After 20s, look for log lines of the form "SharedPortClient - server response deadline has passed for..." referencing the SHADOW communication. Verify that it is indeed about 20s since the shadow tried to initiate contact.
